He claims that: 1 C++ server is roughly equivalent to 40 load-balanced python servers for raw computational power.

name: Starting a tech startup with C++ — Startups, Wanderlust, and Life Hacking

description: I founded a new tech-startup called Signal Analytics with an old University friend, Fedor Dzjuba of Linnworks. We are bu…

data.message: عنده حق بس هي ما بتتحسبش كدة بس

Add the cost of things like:
- Need for higher-priced C++ engineers (and their availability on the market)
- The risk of not finding enough educational resources and/or support libraries
- The additional cost of doing many trivial (yet automated things in dynamic languages) that will add up fastly to the code base and grow its complexity
- The maintainability of the codebase
- The go to market requirements and time constraints
Then you can assess the operational benefits against the development/maintenance overheads needed
Time to market is way longer with C++ . But I can attest to the performance gains.
